headline.main: Launch of Private Rocket Fails; Three Satellites Were Onboard

results.snippet: A privately financed rocket was lost on its way to space, bringing a third failure in a row to an Internet multimillionaire’s effort to create a market for low-cost space-delivery business.
results.lead_paragraph: A privately funded rocket was lost on its way to space Saturday night, bringing a third failure in a row to an Internet multimillionaire's effort to create a market for low-cost space-delivery. The accident occurred a little more than two minutes after launch, and the two-stage Falcon 1 rocket appeared to be oscillating before the live signal from an on-board video camera went dead.

results.lead_paragraph: March 1, 1962, was the first sunny day in New York in weeks. People from across the city were streaming onto Broadway for a ticker-tape parade to honor the astronaut John Glenn.

results.abstract: When a spacecraft headed for Earth orbit was lost Saturday, portions of the cremated remains of 208 people who were being sent into orbit went missing as well.
results.snippet: When a spacecraft headed for Earth orbit was lost Saturday, portions of the cremated remains of 208 people who were being sent into orbit went missing as well.
results.lead_paragraph: When a spacecraft headed for Earth orbit was lost Saturday night, the small satellites for NASA and the Department of Defense were on board. But something else went missing as well from the SpaceX flight: portions of the cremated remains of 208 people who were being sent into orbit by Celestis, a company that offers "Explorer Flight" space burial services. Two of the people whose remains had been on the flight of the SpaceX Falcon 1 were Gordon Cooper , the Mercury astronaut, and James Doohan, the actor who played the wily engineer Montgomery "Scotty" Scott on the original Star Trek series.

results.abstract: Dennis Overbye reviews book The Universe in Mirror: The Sage of the Hubble Space Telescope and the Visionaries Who Built It by Robert Zimmerman; photos (M)

headline.main: Inside Story of the Telescope That Nearly Wasn't Built

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: UNIVERSE IN MIRROR: THE SAGA OF THE HUBBLE SPACE TELESCOPE AND THE VISIONARIES WHO BUILT IT, THE  (BOOK)>

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: UNIVERSE IN MIRROR, THE: THE SAGA OF THE HUBBLE SPACE TELESCOPE AND THE VISIONARIES WHO BUILT IT (BOOK)

results.snippet: “The Universe in Mirror: The Saga of the Hubble Space Telescope and the Visionaries Who Built It” is a breezy behind-the-scenes account.
results.lead_paragraph: Behind every pretty picture of the universe there is a lot of dirty work that had to be done to capture it. When I was covering the space program in the 1980s, at some point during every space mission a NASA public affairs officer would corral a few science reporters and ask what to do when the space telescope was finally launched.

results.abstract: Memorial service held for former New York Yankees outfielder Bobby Murder (M)

headline.main: Yankees Remember the Life of Murcer, With a Nod to Munson

results.snippet: There was a reason the family of Bobby Murcer chose Wednesday to have his memorial service in Oklahoma City.  Thurman Munson was buried on that date 29 years earlier, and Kay Murcer, Bobby's widow, wanted Munson to be part of it.     Munson's wife,...
results.lead_paragraph: There was a reason the family of Bobby Murcer chose Wednesday to have his memorial service in Oklahoma City. Thurman Munson was buried on that date 29 years earlier, and Kay Murcer, Bobby's widow, wanted Munson to be part of it. Munson's wife, Diana, was one of hundreds of friends and family members who filled Memorial Road Church of Christ to honor the life of Murcer, who died of brain cancer on July 12. Derek Jeter and Andy Pettitte represented the Yankees' players, and a large group of club executives, including Hal Steinbrenner and his sister Jennifer Swindal, flew in for the ceremony.

results.abstract: Article on Col Ronald Garan Jr, NASA astronaut and Air Force pilot, native of Yonkers, NY, who recently visited Space Is the Place exhibition at Hudson River Museum; photo (M)

headline.main: View of Space From One Who Was There

results.snippet: Col. Ronald J. Garan Jr., a NASA astronaut and Air Force pilot, talks about what he has seen in space.
results.lead_paragraph: SHORTLY after returning from a 13-day mission on the shuttle Discovery, Col. Ronald J. Garan Jr., a NASA astronaut and Air Force pilot, visited Yonkers, his hometown. In a ceremony at the Hudson River Museum on July 14, he and Mayor Philip A. Amicone exchanged gifts. The mayor presented Colonel Garan with the key to the city, and Colonel Garan (Roosevelt High School, class of 1979) presented Mr. Amicone with items from Yonkers, including school mementos, that he had taken into space. While touring the museum's current exhibition, ''Space Is the Place,'' Colonel Garan took special interest in paintings by Lia Halloran that show astronautlike figures, and an audio installation, ''Indecision on the Moon,'' by Nina Katchadourian, that replays Neil A. Armstrong's lunar landing, but none of his famous words. Speaking by phone from Houston, Colonel Garan, 46, noted that his mother, Linda Relis, is a wildlife artist in Florida whose naturalistic oil paintings hang in the State House. For that reason, he said, he is more accustomed to ''technically accurate'' than conceptual art. On the other hand, he said, referring to the Yonkers show, ''You can't help but be impressed with some of the creativity.''

results.abstract: Benjamin Genocchio reviews Space Is the Place exhibition at Hudson River Museum in Yonkers; photo (M)
results.snippet: “Space Is the Place” is one of those goofy but enjoyable theme exhibitions that every now and then arrive at regional museums.
results.lead_paragraph: ''Space Is the Place'' is one of those goofy but enjoyable theme exhibitions that every now and then arrive at regional museums. They are invariably package shows, organized elsewhere and brought in to fill a gap in the exhibition program or because of a connection to the community or the museum itself. Since the Hudson River Museum is home to a popular planetarium, it makes sense that it would host a show on space and space exploration. Then there is the added hook that on July 20 the nation observed the 39th anniversary of the first moon landing, by Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin.

results.abstract: Article discusses how the president of the United States has been portrayed on television, the actors who played the part and some of the roles these actors had before playing the president; actors include Gary Sinise, Geena Davis, Randy Quaid, Patty Duke, Kenneth Branagh and Dennis Haysbert; photos (L)

headline.main: Do Some Voodoo, So You, Too, Can Be President

results.snippet: A look at the former robbers, nuns and voodoo worshipers who would be president, at least in prime time.
results.lead_paragraph: AFTER more than 230 years the paths to the presidency are fairly well established. John McCain is hoping to follow what might be thought of as the John F. Kennedy Route: war hero to United States senator to president. Barack Obama is pursuing the Warren G. Harding Route: orator-organizer to United States senator to president. A lawyership, a governorship, a cabinet post, a vice presidency all are common stepping stones to the White House, but not all our chief executives have had such staid, predictable résumés. We have had presidents who were once bank robbers, pirates, devotees of voodoo. We have had a president who was elected, then developed a second career as a ruthless murderer, and then was re-elected. We have even had a president who was previously a first lady. She also logged time as a nun. These commanders in chief were some of our many television presidents. Before they attained the White House, these men and women, or the actors who played them, turned up in all sorts of roles that would never have passed muster with the American people had we had the chance to vet them properly. Film presidents too have their odd backgrounds -- FredricMarch, president in ''Seven Days in May,'' was both Jekyll and Hyde before being elected -- but, modern conventions being TV events, it seems fitting to focus on the small screen. Here are a few of the more bizarre paths that have led to television presidencies. The Gary Sinise Route

headline.main: THE GARY SINISE ROUTE PAROLE-JUMPING WANDERER TO POST-APOCALYPTIC WANDERER TO WAR HERO TO OUTER-SPACE WANDERER TO PRESIDENT.

results.snippet: Mr. Sinise was Tom Joad in a 1991 adaptation of Steinbeck's ''Grapes of Wrath,'' a story that begins with Joad bring released from prison and later turns him into a cop-killing fugitive. Three years later he was the lone survivor in his Texas town of...
results.lead_paragraph: Mr. Sinise was Tom Joad in a 1991 adaptation of Steinbeck's ''Grapes of Wrath,'' a story that begins with Joad bring released from prison and later turns him into a cop-killing fugitive. Three years later he was the lone survivor in his Texas town of a plague in a TV version of ''The Stand,'' one of Stephen King's sprawling nightmares. That same year he was a scruffy, legless Vietnam veteran in ''Forrest Gump.'' Then, legs restored, came a stint as an astronaut in ''Apollo 13'' in 1995 (his Ken Mattingly didn't make that trip but did fly on Apollo 16), followed by immediate election to the White House: he had the title role in the 1995 TV movie ''Truman.'' EERIE CONNECTIONS TO OTHER PRESIDENTS Mr. Sinise also spent time as a Watergate prosecutor, playing Richard Ben-Veniste in the ABC movie ''The Final Days'' in 1989.
